description:
Title: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Vulnerability

Description:

A cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability has been identified in the application's login page. An attacker can inject malicious code into the application, which is then executed when a victim user visits the page. This can lead to various security breaches such as stealing user credentials, session hijacking, and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Impact:

If exploited, this vulnerability could allow an attacker to gain access to sensitive information, manipulate user sessions, and execute malicious code on the victim's browser.

Mitigation:

To mitigate this vulnerability, it is recommended to implement input validation and output encoding to ensure that all user inputs are properly sanitized. Additionally, implementing content security policies and using HTTP-only cookies can also help prevent XSS attacks. It is also important to keep the application and all its components up-to-date with the latest security patches and updates.

description:
One morning, when Gregor Samsa woke from troubled dreams. One morning, when Gregor Samsa woke from troubled dreams, he found himself *transformed* in his bed into a horrible [vermin](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vermin "Wikipedia Vermin"). He lay on his armour-like back, and if he lifted his head a little he could see his brown belly, slightly domed and divided by arches into stiff sections. The bedding was hardly able to cover **strong** it and seemed ready to slide off any moment. His many legs, pitifully thin compared with the size of the rest of him, link waved abouthelplessly as he looked. “What's happened to me?” he thought. It wasn't a dream. His room, a proper human room although a little too small, lay peacefully between its four familiar walls.

## The bedding was hardly able to cover it. It showed a lady fitted out with a fur hat and fur boa who sat upright, raising a heavy fur muff that covered the whole of her lower arm towards the viewer a solid fur muff into which her entire forearm disappeared.. ### Things we know about Gregor's sleeping habits. - He always slept on his right side. - He has to get up early (to start another dreadful day). - He has a drawer and a alarm clock next to his bed. - His mother calls him when he gets up to late.

description:
Title: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Vulnerability

Description:

A cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability has been identified in the application's login page. An attacker can inject malicious code into the application, which is then executed when a victim user visits the page. This can lead to various security breaches such as stealing user credentials, session hijacking, and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Impact:

If exploited, this vulnerability could allow an attacker to gain access to sensitive information, manipulate user sessions, and execute malicious code on the victim's browser.

Mitigation:

To mitigate this vulnerability, it is recommended to implement input validation and output encoding to ensure that all user inputs are properly sanitized. Additionally, implementing content security policies and using HTTP-only cookies can also help prevent XSS attacks. It is also important to keep the application and all its components up-to-date with the latest security patches and updates.

title: Sensitive Credentials in a world-readable file on the webserver
issueType: Sensitive database credentials were found in an environmental variable file.
remark:
Add the following code to a .htaccess file on the webserver
# Disable index view
Options -Indexes
# Hide a specific file
<Files .env>
	Order allow,deny
	Deny from all
</Files>
impact: Sensitive credentials found can be further misused to login in a portal like phpmyadmin and access more sensitive data.

description:
# Duplicate
This indicates that the issue has already been reported previously. If an issue has already been reported, it is important to attribute the discovery of the issue to the original discoverer in order to build trust and give credit where it is due. This can be done by linking the current report to a previous report via some identifying information, such as a report ID or other Unique identifier/Attachments. Additionally, it can be helpful to include details about the original discovery of the issue, such as the time and date of the original report, in order to provide a complete and accurate record of the issue's history.
By taking these steps, organisations can demonstrate their commitment to transparency and fairness, and help to build trust with the hacking community.

title: Sensitive Credentials in a world-readable file on the webserver
issueType: Sensitive database credentials were found in an environmental variable file.
remark:
Add the following code to a .htaccess file on the webserver
# Disable index view
Options -Indexes
# Hide a specific file

	Deny from all
</Files>
impact: Sensitive credentials found can be further misused to login in a portal like phpmyadmin and access more sensitive data.

description:
Visit www.google.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Account Takeover via Password Reset Poisoning
issueType: Password reset poisoning is an attack where the attacker intercepts or manipulates the password reset process to gain unauthorized access, potentially leading to sensitive information theft, unauthorized transactions, and damage to the victim's reputation.
remark: Use $_SERVER['SERVER_NAME'] rather than $_SERVER['HTTP_HOST'] while generating password reset link.
impact: Password reset poisoning is a type of attack where an attacker intercepts or manipulates the process of resetting a password in order to gain unauthorized access to an account. This can have serious consequences, including the theft of sensitive information, unauthorized purchases or transfers, and damage to the victim's reputation. It is important to use secure methods for password reset and to be vigilant in monitoring for suspicious activity.

description:
Visit www.ultim.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Account Takeover via Password Reset Poisoning

It is important to use secure methods for password reset and to be vigilant in monitoring for suspicious activity.

remark: The search parameter should be properly sanitized to prevent the injection of malicious code. Additionally, input validation should be implemented to ensure that only expected characters are accepted.
impact: Reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) is commonly used to steal sensitive information or to launch other attacks, such as phishing or malware delivery.

description:
Visit www.google.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Server-Side Parameter Tampering leading to payment bypass
issueType: The payable amount for the company's subscription models can be changed by the user
remark: The parameter `amount` should not be available to the users to mutate.
impact: Users can avail benefits of premium subscriptions without paying

description:
Visit www.google.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Subdomain Takeover - S3 Bucket Misconfiguration
issueType: Subdomain takeover vulnerability on non-existent S3 bucket, enabling attacker control.
remark: Remove the s3.target.com DNS entry so it no longer points to an S3 bucket.
impact: An attacker can take control of an S3 bucket that is improperly configured and use it to host malicious content. This can lead to phishing attacks, malware distribution, and other security breaches.

description:
Visit www.google.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Command execution via custom php files
issueType: Any php file can be executed placed anywhere on the webserver
remark: Disable php-script execution by restricting access to any php files in the profile-pictures folder
impact: With the use of this, a malicious entity can take over the web-server as a non-privileged user and further, it acts as a foothold which gives access to the system for further enumeration and possibility of a complete take-over of the server.

description:
Visit www.google.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Account Takeover via Password Reset Poisoning
issueType: Password reset poisoning is an attack where the attacker intercepts or manipulates the password reset process to gain unauthorized access, potentially leading to sensitive information theft, unauthorized transactions, and damage to the victim's reputation.
remark: Use $_SERVER['SERVER_NAME'] rather than $_SERVER['HTTP_HOST'] while generating password reset link.
impact: Password reset poisoning is a type of attack where an attacker intercepts or manipulates the process of resetting a password in order to gain unauthorized access to an account. This can have serious consequences, including the theft of sensitive information, unauthorized purchases or transfers, and damage to the victim's reputation. It is important to use secure methods for password reset and to be vigilant in monitoring for suspicious activity.

description:
Visit example.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Command execution via custom php files
issueType: Any php file can be executed placed anywhere on the webserver
remark: Disable php-script execution by restricting access to any php files in the profile-pictures folder
impact: With the use of this, a malicious entity can take over the web-server as a non-privileged user and further, it acts as a foothold which gives access to the system for further enumeration and possibility of a complete take-over of the server.

description:
Visit example.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Sensitive Credentials in a world-readable file on the webserver
issueType: Sensitive database credentials were found in an environmental variable file.
remark:

# Disable index view
Options -Indexes

	Deny from all
</Files>

description:
Visit example.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Subdomain Takeover - S3 Bucket Misconfiguration
issueType: Subdomain takeover vulnerability on non-existent S3 bucket, enabling attacker control.
remark: Remove the s3.target.com DNS entry so it no longer points to an S3 bucket.
impact: An attacker can take control of an S3 bucket that is improperly configured and use it to host malicious content. This can lead to phishing attacks, malware distribution, and other security breaches.

description:
Visit example.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Unauthorized Write Access to S3 Bucket
issueType: S3 bucket was configured with public write access.
remark: Use S3 Access Control Lists (ACLs) to manage access to individual objects within a bucket.
impact: An attacker with access to the S3 bucket can upload malicious files, such as malware or phishing content, which can be used to compromise the security of the organization and its customers.

description:
Visit example.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Account Takeover via Password Reset Poisoning
issueType: Password reset poisoning is an attack where the attacker intercepts or manipulates the password reset process to gain unauthorized access, potentially leading to sensitive information theft, unauthorized transactions, and damage to the victim's reputation.
remark: Use $_SERVER['SERVER_NAME'] rather than $_SERVER['HTTP_HOST'] while generating password reset link.
impact: Password reset poisoning is a type of attack where an attacker intercepts or manipulates the process of resetting a password in order to gain unauthorized access to an account. This can have serious consequences, including the theft of sensitive information, unauthorized purchases or transfers, and damage to the victim's reputation. It is important to use secure methods for password reset and to be vigilant in monitoring for suspicious activity.

description:
1. Subdomain Takeover can be tested via sub404[https://github.com/r3curs1v3-pr0xy/sub404]
2. `python3 sub404.py -d ripl.com`
title: Subdomain Takeover on Multiple URLs
issueType: Basic Subdomain Takeover
remark:
- This can be prevented by removing the DNS-configuration of the external service on the subdomain.
- All such subdomains need to be monitored and kept track of properly.
impact:
- Subdomain Takeover can be a very serious vulnerability and can lead to many phishing campaigns being run on the subdomain with the user thinking they are interacting with ripl.com
- Even Intrusion Detection Systems do not track this, hence this could lead to the vulnerability completely destroying the credibility of the company.
- Cookies can be stolen along with valuable credentials like admin account passwords etc.

The X-Frame-Options header is missing and CSP Headers are missing anti-framing policies
title: Clickjacking
issueType: Clickjacking
remark:
- This can be easily prevented by setting X-Frame-Options to either deny(safest) or sameorigin(less safer)
- Can be done on apache using `Header set X-Frame-Options "DENY"`
- This vulnerability can also be mitigated via CSP by adding `Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'none';` to the headers.
impact: - Clickjacking on main page containing a pop-up to login can be used to steal credentials like username-password from users

description:
- It was detected that your web application doesn't implement Content Security Policy (CSP) as the CSP header is missing from the response.
- This can be confirmed by basic GET/POST requests to https://app.ripl.com
title: CSP headers missing
issueType: Content-Security-Policy
impact: CSP can be used to prevent and/or mitigate attacks that involve content/code injection, such as cross-site scripting/XSS attacks, attacks that require embedding a malicious resource, attacks that involve malicious use of iframes, such as clickjacking attacks, and others.

description: Referrer Policy controls behavior of the Referer header, which indicates the origin or web page URL the request was made from. The web application uses insecure Referrer Policy configuration that may leak user's information to third-party sites.
title: Insecure Referer Policy
issueType: Referer
remark:
- Its best if the referrer policy is moved to a stricter measure. 

eg. `Referrer-Policy : strict-origin-when-cross-origin` is a safer alternative and can prevent some issues.
impact: This misconfiguration can sometimes be used to leak a user's private data.

description:
- Session Timeouts are designed to log users out after a period of no activity.
- It is aimed to protect users from various social engineering techniques and expiring all the tokens and session data as soon as the user timeouts.
title: Session does not expire.
issueType: Long Timeout
remark:
This can be mitigated by logging the user out after a period of (say) ten minutes.
That way the user would need to login again after the said ten minutes and if left idle, the session wont stay alive.
impact:
- This vulnerability can be leveraged by a malicious entity by accessing a user's computer without their permission either physically or remotely.
- On its own, it does not pose a direct risk, but it can facilitate a lot other persistent attacks.

description:
Ideal/Model Password Policies requires a password/passphrase which:
- Is more than 8 letters long.
- Contains atleast one number.
- Contains atleast one small letter.
- Contains atleast one captial letter.
- Contains atleast one symbol.
- Should not contains the username/email-id in some form
- Should not be the same as the last(three) passwords.
title: Password Policy is poor
issueType: Change Password
remark:
This can be easily mitigated by checking the password for the following checks and ensuring that the password is not the easiest to crack.

Ideal/Model Password Policies requires a password/passphrase which:
- Is more than 8 letters long.
- Contains atleast one number.
- Contains atleast one small letter.
- Contains atleast one captial letter.
- Contains atleast one symbol.
- Should not contains the username/email-id in some form
- Should not be the same as the last(three) passwords.
impact:
- In case of some intrusion, if a malicious entity finds a database of encrypted passwords, they can easily crack the simple ones within seconds.
- A poor password policy allows the users to set these weak passwords which can be cracked very easily.
- This hypothetical attack could lead to an account and its data/digital property to be stolen.

description:
A password change mechanism require the following from the user:
- the old password.
- a new password which follows the password policy
- MFA authentication (if any)

And post the change, it is supposed to serve a notification to the user to let them know that their password has been changed so that if there is some suspicious activity, they can alert the concerned parties.
title: Insecure Password Change Mechanism
issueType: Weak Password Reset Implementation
remark:
This can be solved by including the following steps in the process:
- Requiring the old password.
- Providing a notification to user post the change.
- Removing the auth_token as the basis of identifying a user and replacing with a session/CSRF token.
- Involving more dynamic elements required to change a password which wont be of any use on session expiry.
impact:
```
PUT /auth.json?auth_token=VmC3w7EafeJAQmNsL7_s&client_id=com.ripl.browser&client_version=2022.9.21_814&dev_mode=false&time_zone_offset=19800 HTTP/1.1
Host: api.ripl.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:91.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/91.0
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: https://app.ripl.com/
Content-Type: application/json
Origin: https://app.ripl.com
Content-Length: 32
Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty
Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-site
Te: trailers
Connection: close

{"user":{"password":"abcdefgh"}}
```
- The above request is required to change the password of the user `teji pen`{tejipen664@geekjun.com}
- This static request allows anyone to change the password of the user.
- The only thing that lets the APi know what user this is, is the auth_token which is a static entity which doesn't change on a user logging out.
- This means that if this auth_token gets leaked then the user gets hacked forever since the hacker can change their password anytime they want.
- Paired with the fact that there is no Multi-factor authentication, this poses a serious threat to the user and may lead to account takeovers.

description:
- Sign in Attempts should have a maximum of 5 unsuccessful tries allowed before serving a temporarily timeout to the user
- This is done in order to prevent excessive requests which can be used for something like a bruteforce attack on a particular user.

```
POST /auth/sign_in.json?client_id=com.ripl.browser&client_version=2022.9.21_814&dev_mode=false&time_zone_offset=19800 HTTP/1.1
Host: api.ripl.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:91.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/91.0
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: https://app.ripl.com/
Content-Type: application/json
Origin: https://app.ripl.com
Content-Length: 91
Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty
Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-site
Te: trailers
Connection: close
 
{"user":{"email":"tejipen664@geekjun.com","password":"§abc§"},"channel_tracking_parameters":{},"pro_preview":true}
```

The above request when sent to Intruder on Burp Suite is allowed to make upto 25 requests in 30 seconds.
title: Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts
issueType: Brute Force
remark:
- Mitigation from this attack is very easy.
- All the api has to do is ban the email-id for (say) 5 minutes from making any authentication requests for every (say) 5 wrong authentication attempts.
- This can easily prevent the attack from happening in its early stages.
impact:
- A brute Force attack is on its own not very serious since it can be detected easily and blocked.
- However coupled with the fact that easy passwords are allowed and there is no timeout, it can pose a serious problem and in the worst case lead to account takeovers.

description:
Application is signed with SHA1withRSA. SHA1 hash algorithm is known to have collision issues.

The use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm is an unnecessary risk that may result in the disclosure of sensitive information.

The use of a non-standard algorithm is dangerous because a determined attacker may be able to break the algorithm and compromise whatever data has been protected. Well-known techniques may exist to break the algorithm.
title: Certificate algorithm vulnerable to hash collision
issueType: Cryptographic Flaw
remark:
Do not develop your own cryptographic algorithms. They will likely be exposed to attacks that are well-understood by cryptographers. Reverse engineering techniques are mature. If your algorithm can be compromised if attackers find out how it works, then it is especially weak.

Use a well-vetted algorithm that is currently considered to be strong by experts in the field, and select well-tested implementations.

As with all cryptographic mechanisms, the source code should be available for analysis.

Periodically ensure that you aren't using obsolete cryptography. 

Design your app so that you can replace one cryptographic algorithm with another. This will make it easier to upgrade to stronger algorithms.

Carefully manage and protect cryptographic keys. If the keys can be guessed or stolen, then the strength of the cryptography itself is irrelevant.

Industry-standard implementations will save you development time and may be more likely to avoid errors that can occur during implementation of cryptographic algorithms. Consider the ESAPI SecurityDatabase\Encrypt\Encryption feature.
impact:
Attacker may be able to create a APK with his malicious code, and identical SHA1 digest of your genuine files. Devices that had previous version will consider the crafted APK to be signed by your certificate, and issue no warning when installing it.
	
The confidentiality of sensitive data may be compromised by the use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm.

The integrity of sensitive data may be compromised by the use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm.

Any accountability to message content preserved by cryptography may be subject to attack.

description:
The app, upon installation, sets incorrect permissions for an object that exposes it to an unintended actor.

Android.Permission- READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE is set to true
title: Permission allowed to  Read Internal Storage
issueType: Local Attack Vector
remark:
"android.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE" must be set to false 
if it is not necessary for an App to Function properly

Affected file :
"AndroidManifest.xml"   line no- 14

Very carefully manage the setting, management and handling of permissions. Explicitly manage trust zones in the app.

Ensure that appropriate compartmentalization is built into the system design and that the compartmentalization serves to allow for and further reinforce privilege separation functionality. Architects and designers should rely on the principle of least privilege to decide when it is appropriate to use and to drop system privileges.
impact:
Allows an application to read content from external storage.

Attacker may be able to read files from local storage and it exposes sensitive data.

Ensure that appropriate compartmentalization is built into the app design and that the compartmentalization serves to allow for and further reinforce privilege separation functionality. description:
The App transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel (HTTP, FTP) that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors. The information should be encrypted or otherwise protected.

Many communication channels can be "sniffed" by attackers during data transmission. For example, network traffic can often be sniffed by any attacker who has access to a network interface. This significantly lowers the difficulty of exploitation by attackers.
title: App transmits sensitive data in cleartext in a comminication channel.
issueType: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Data
remark:
Affected File:

"AndroidManifext.xml" line no- 47

Encrypt the data with a reliable encryption scheme before transmitting.

Use SSL for the entire session from login to logout, not just for the initial login page.

Use tools and techniques that require manual (human) analysis, such as penetration testing, threat modeling, and interactive tools that allow the tester to record and modify an active session. These may be more effective than strictly automated techniques. This is especially the case with weaknesses that are related to design and business rules.

Use monitoring tools that examine the process as it interacts with the operating system and the network. This technique is useful in cases when source code is unavailable, if the software was not developed by you, or if you want to verify that the build phase did not introduce any new weaknesses. 

Configure servers to use encrypted channels for communication, which may include SSL or other secure protocols.
impact: Cleartext traffic results in  lack of confidentiality, authenticity, and protections against tampering. A attacker can eavesdrop on transmitted data and can read the information by gaining access to the channel being used for communication.

description: If task affinity is set, it allows other applications to read the Intents sent to Activities belonging to another task.
title: TaskAffinity is set for Activity
issueType: Mobile Security Misconfiguration
remark:
Affected File

"com.urbanairship.push.NotificationProxyActivity"

Always use the default setting keeping the affinity as the package name in order to prevent sensitive information inside sent or received Intents from being read by another application.
impact: Other applications could read the Intents sent to Activities belonging to another task.

description:
Google api key is hardcoded and it is strored in strings.xml file
Attacker can reverse engineer the app and can get hold of the key

"google_api_key" : "AIzaSyDUvC7lPEevJzEKdDIOLWZFK2qAnM9vGh8"


The app contains hard-coded credential, a API Key. Which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components.

A hard-coded API KEY typically leads to a significant authentication failure that can be difficult for the system administrator to detect. Once detected, it can be difficult to fix, so the administrator may be forced into disabling the API Service entirely.

The app connects to another service , and it contains hard-coded Keys for connecting and using that component.
title: Google API Key is leaked
issueType: Disclosure of Secrets
remark:
Affected file:
"/res/values/string.xml" line no- 409

API key should not be leak and hardcoded. It should be encrypt before storing it.

Only administrators should have access to the Google API keys used by your application.

As a consequence, Google API keys should not be stored along with the application code as they could be disclosed to a large audience or could be made public.

Google API keys should be stored outside of the code in a file that is never committed to your application code repository.

If possible, a better alternative is to use your cloud provider’s service for managing secrets. On Google Cloud this service is called Secret Manager.

When credentials are disclosed in the application code, consider them as compromised and revoke them immediately.

In addition to secure storage, it’s important to apply restrictions to API keys in order to mitigate the impacts when they are discovered by malicious actors.
impact:
An unrestricted Google API key being disclosed in a public source code would be used by malicious actors to consume Google APIs on the behalf of your application. This will have a financial impact as your organization will be billed for the data consumed by the malicious actor.

 If your account has enabled quota to cap the API consumption of your application, this quota can be exceeded, leaving your application unable to request the Google APIs it requires to function properly.

description:
- When a forgot password request is triggered, the registered email id receives a link to reset the password associated with the account.
- Ideally the reset link should expire in (max) 5 minutes and/or if is it already used once
- eg. "https://app.ripl.com/account/resetPassword?token=FMbh4zbQJN75Q5ymw3W2" can be used to reset the password of the account "sopixi3890@orlydns.com" by anyone at anytime.
- Not only this, but "https://app.ripl.com/account/resetPassword?token=c5-DXisp9PzzxtYUo3bC" can also be used to do the same. This means these link do not expire even when new ones are created to reset the password.
title: Weak Password Recovery/Forgot Password Mechanism
issueType: On Password Reset
remark:
The mitigation for these vulnerabilities are not very complex and can improve the overall security of the application and data.
- The reset password links be expired in 5 minutes.
- The reset password links be expired once they have been used.
- Not more than one reset link be active for one user at a time.
- Confirm change of password via email to notify users.
impact:
- These are high impact vulnerabilities since if someone grabs the URL on which the query is being made, then the account associated with the query gets permanently hacked since this link can be used to change the password at any time.
- Not only that, but since the links stay active all the time, it isn't feasible to manually remove the active links on the demand of clients either.

description:
Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.
Extended Description

While logging all information may be helpful during development stages, it is important that logging levels be set appropriately before a product ships so that sensitive user data and system information are not accidentally exposed to potential attackers.
title: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File
issueType: Sensitive Data Exposure
remark:
Logs must be check strictly to ensure that no sensitive information is logged.

Consider seriously the sensitivity of the information written into log files. Do not write secrets into the log files.

Protect log files against unauthorized read/write.

Adjust configurations appropriately when software is transitioned from a debug state to production.
impact:
Logging sensitive user data often provides attackers with an additional, less-protected path to acquiring the information.
Attacker can read the sensitive information which is written to logs.

description:
The software constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not sanitize or incorrectly sanitizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

Without sufficient removal or quoting of SQL syntax in user-controllable inputs, the generated SQL query can cause those inputs to be interpreted as SQL instead of ordinary user data. This can be used to alter query logic to bypass security checks, or to insert additional statements that modify the back-end database, possibly including execution of system commands.

SQL injection has become a common issue with database-driven apps using SQLite Databases. The flaw is easily detected, and easily exploited, and as such, any app or software package with even a minimal user base is likely to be subject to an attempted attack of this kind. This flaw depends on the fact that SQL makes no real distinction between the control and data planes.
title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command
issueType: SQL Injection
remark:
1) Parameterization

If available, use structured mechanisms that automatically enforce the separation between data and code. These mechanisms may be able to provide the relevant quoting, encoding, and validation automatically, instead of relying on the developer to provide this capability at every point where output is generated.

Process SQL queries using prepared statements, parameterized queries, or stored procedures. These features should accept parameters or variables and support strong typing. Do not dynamically construct and execute query strings within these features using "exec" or similar functionality, since you may re-introduce the possibility of SQL injection.

2) Least Privilege

Follow the principle of least privilege when creating user accounts to a SQL database. The database users should only have the minimum privileges necessary to use their account. If the requirements of the system indicate that a user can read and modify their own data, then limit their privileges so they cannot read/write others' data. Use the strictest permissions possible on all database objects, such as execute-only for stored procedures.

3)Perform Client and Server Side Checks

For any security checks that are performed on the client side, ensure that these checks are duplicated on the server side. Attackers can bypass the client-side checks by modifying values after the checks have been performed, or by changing the client to remove the client-side checks entirely. Then, these modified values would be submitted to the server.

4)Input Validation

Assume all input is malicious. Use an "accept known good" input validation strategy, i.e., use a whitelist of acceptable inputs that strictly conform to specifications. Reject any input that does not strictly conform to specifications, or transform it into something that does. Do not rely exclusively on looking for malicious or malformed inputs (i.e., do not rely on a blacklist). However, blacklists can be useful for detecting potential attacks or determining which inputs are so malformed that they should be rejected outright.
impact:
Since SQL databases generally hold sensitive data, loss of confidentiality is a frequent problem with SQL injection vulnerabilities.

Authentication:
If poor SQL commands are used to check user names and passwords, it may be possible to connect to a system as another user with no previous knowledge of the password.

Authorization:
If authorization information is held in a SQL database, it may be possible to change this information through the successful exploitation of a SQL injection vulnerability.

Integrity:
Just as it may be possible to read sensitive information, it is also possible to make changes or even delete this information with a SQL injection attack.

description:
App copies data to clipboard.  As other applications can accessed those data, sensitive and confidential data can be leaked

The attacker can exploits an application that allows for the copying of sensitive data or information by collecting information copied to the clipboard.
title: Data is copied to Clipboard and can be accessed by an Attacker
issueType: Sensitive Data Exposure
remark:
The data stored in clipboard should be protected and not accessible by other applications

While copying and pasting of data with the clipboard is a legitimate and practical function, certain situations and context may require the disabling of this feature. Just as certain applications disable screenshot capability, applications that handle highly sensitive information should consider disabling copy and paste functionality.

Employ a robust identification and audit/blocking via using an allowlist of applications on your app.
impact:
Data copied to the clipboard can be accessed by other applications, such as malware built to exfiltrate or log clipboard contents on a periodic basis. In this way, the attacker aims to garner information to which they are unauthorized.

Users sensitive and confidential data can be leaked and Attacker can use it to further escalate the attack.

description:
The app uses insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers.

When software generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information.
title: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
issueType: Broken Cryptography
remark:
Phase: Architecture and Design

Use a well-vetted algorithm that is currently considered to be strong by experts in the field, and select well-tested implementations with adequate length seeds.

In general, if a pseudo-random number generator is not advertised as being cryptographically secure, then it is probably a statistical PRNG and should not be used in security-sensitive contexts.

Pseudo-random number generators can produce predictable numbers if the generator is known and the seed can be guessed. A 256-bit seed is a good starting point for producing a "random enough" number.

Phase: Implementation

Consider a PRNG that re-seeds itself as needed from high quality pseudo-random output sources, such as hardware devices.

Phase: Testing

Use automated static analysis tools that target this type of weakness. Many modern techniques use data flow analysis to minimize the number of false positives. This is not a perfect solution, since 100% accuracy and coverage are not feasible.

Phase: Testing

Perform FIPS 140-2 tests on data to catch obvious entropy problems.

Phase: Testing

Use tools and techniques that require manual (human) analysis, such as penetration testing, threat modeling, and interactive tools that allow the tester to record and modify an active session. These may be more effective than strictly automated techniques. This is especially the case with weaknesses that are related to design and business rules.
impact:
When a protection mechanism relies on random values to restrict access to a sensitive resource, such as a session ID or a seed for generating a cryptographic key, then the resource being protected could be accessed by guessing the ID or key.

If software relies on unique, unguessable IDs to identify a resource, an attacker might be able to guess an ID for a resource that is owned by another user. The attacker could then read the resource, or pre-create a resource with the same ID to prevent the legitimate program from properly sending the resource to the intended user. 

When an authorization or authentication mechanism relies on random values to restrict access to restricted functionality, such as a session ID or a seed for generating a cryptographic key, then an attacker may access the restricted functionality by guessing the ID or key.

If the random number generator algorithm is not strong then the attacker can break the cryptography,  predict the next numbers.
Which can compromise the data encrypted using this Cryptography.

description:
The software, upon installation, sets incorrect permissions for an object that exposes it to an unintended actor.

It also creates the temporary files. Sensitive information should not be  written into this files.
title: Incorrect Default Permissions
issueType: Insecure Data Storage
remark:
1)Phase: Architecture and Design

Ensure that appropriate compartmentalization is built into the system design and that the compartmentalization serves to allow for and further reinforce privilege separation functionality. Architects and designers should rely on the principle of least privilege to decide when it is appropriate to use and to drop system privileges.

2)Avoid storing data into the temporary files. And if it is not possible then make sure the data stored is properly encrypted and can not be accessed by other applications or an attacker

Very carefully manage the setting, management and handling of permissions. Explicitly manage trust zones in the software.
impact: The Temporary files are created by app and if these files store sensitive information then attacker can use this sensitive information to escalate the attack and compromise the application

description:
App provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function (Webview) that is not properly restricted.

This weakness can lead to a wide variety of resultant weaknesses, depending on the behavior of the exposed method.
title: Improper Platform Usage
issueType: Exposed Sensitive Android Intent
remark:
1)Phase: Architecture and Design

If you must expose a method, make sure to perform input validation on all arguments, limit access to authorized parties, and protect against all possible vulnerabilities.

2)Phases: Architecture and Design; Implementation

Strategy: Identify and Reduce Attack Surface

Identify all exposed functionality. Explicitly list all functionality that must be exposed to some user or set of users. Identify which functionality may be:

accessible to all users

restricted to a small set of privileged users

prevented from being directly accessible at all

Ensure that the implemented code follows these expectations. This includes setting the appropriate access modifiers where applicable (public, private, protected, etc.) or not marking ActiveX controls safe-for-scripting.
impact:
The exposure can occur in a few different ways:

1) The function/method was never intended to be exposed to outside actors.

2) The function/method was only intended to be accessible to a limited set of actors, such as Internet-based access from a single web site.

Exposing critical functionality essentially provides an attacker with the privilege level of the exposed functionality. This could result in the modification or exposure of sensitive data or possibly even execution of arbitrary code.

description:
The Android application exports a component for use by other applications, but does not properly restrict which applications can launch the component or access the data it contains.
 Improper Export of Deep Link Url Activity.
title: Deeplink Url Activity is not Protected
issueType: Exposed Sensitive Android Intent
remark:
"AndroidManifest.xml" on line no- 169

Strategy: Attack Surface Reduction

If the activity do not need to be shared by other applications, explicitly mark components with android:exported="false" in the application manifest.

If you only intend to use exported components between related apps under your control, use android:protectionLevel="signature" in the xml manifest to restrict access to applications signed by you.
impact: If access to an exported Activity is not restricted, any application will be able to launch the activity. This may allow a malicious application to gain access to sensitive information, modify the internal state of the application, or trick a user into interacting with the victim application while believing they are still interacting with the malicious application.

description:
The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product.
The app fails to detect the rooted device and the use of Frida.
title: Fails to detect rooted device and Frida
issueType: Lack of Jailbreak Detection
remark:
1. Implementing emulator detection
Having emulator detection gives one layer of additional projection to your application against runtime manipulation.

2.Google SafetyNet
SafetyNet is an Android API that creates profiles of devices according to software and hardware information and then compares it to a list of whitelisted device models, which have cleared Android compatibility testing.

3.Basic Integrity check
Basic Integrity gives a signal about the general integrity of the device and its API. Many rooted devices emulators, virtual devices, and devices with signs of tampering (such as API hooks) fail basic Integrity checks.
impact:
A rooted device renders the user permissions useless.
Running an unwarranted app on it is an obvious security risk.
Apps which do not check for rooted device hamper security.

This allows changing of another username's password

impact: With the use of this, a malicious entity can take over the web-server as a non-privileged user and further, it acts as a foothold which gives access to the system for further enumeration and possibility of a complete take-over of the server.

This allows changing of another username's password

issueType: Subdomain takeover vulnerability on non-existent S3 bucket, enabling attacker control.
remark: Remove the s3.target.com DNS entry so it no longer points to an S3 bucket.
impact: An attacker can take control of an S3 bucket that is improperly configured and use it to host malicious content. This can lead to phishing attacks, malware distribution, and other security breaches.

description:
Visit www.google.com-> Settings -> Reset pass -> Enter any other username .

This allows changing of another username's password
title: Unauthorized Write Access to S3 Bucket
issueType: S3 bucket was configured with public write access.
remark: Use S3 Access Control Lists (ACLs) to manage access to individual objects within a bucket.

It is important to use secure methods for password reset and to be vigilant in monitoring for suspicious activity.

description:
### Reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)

### Description
A reflected XSS **vulnerability** has been discovered on the search page of example.com. An attacker can inject malicious *code* into the search parameter, which is then executed by the victim's browser when the search results are displayed. This can be used to steal sensitive information or launch other attacks.

### Security Impact
An attacker can steal sensitive information, such as login credentials, by injecting code that exfiltrates this information. Additionally, the attacker can use this vulnerability to launch other attacks, such as phishing or malware delivery.

Steps to reproduce
Navigate to http://example.com/search?q=<script>alert(document.cookie);</script>
When this URL is visited by an user, a pop-up box will appear displaying the user's cookies.

Specifics
If applicable, what account were you using to test?
e.g. bugbasetest@gmail.com
If applicable, what domain(s) does this vulnerability affect?
e.g. example.com
Does this only affect specific versions or vendors?
e.g. No
Recommendations
The search parameter should be properly sanitized to prevent the injection of malicious code. Additionally, input validation should be implemented to ensure that only expected characters are accepted.
